title: Problem Overview
content: This module formalizes **Erdős Problem #918**: Two questions about chromatic numbers of infinite graphs. Can a graph have very large chromatic number while all smaller subgraphs remain countably chromatic?
mathContext: The main questions are OPEN. Question 1 asks about ℵ₂-chromatic graphs; Question 2 asks about ℵ_{ω+1}-chromatic graphs. Erdős-Hajnal (1968) proved the phenomenon exists for finite aleph numbers.

title: Imports and Setup
content: We import Mathlib modules for **cardinal arithmetic** (Cardinal.Basic) and **ordinal numbers** (Cardinal.Ordinal). The aleph function maps ordinals to infinite cardinals.
mathContext: Cardinal.mk gives the cardinality of a type. The aleph function ℵ_α is defined for all ordinals α. We use these to state conditions like 'graph has ℵ₂ vertices'.

title: Infinite Chromatic Numbers
content: For **infinite graphs**, chromatic number must be a cardinal, not a natural number. A graph is κ-colorable if its vertices can be colored with κ colors such that adjacent vertices have different colors.
mathContext: Mathlib's SimpleGraph.chromaticNumber returns ℕ, suitable for finite graphs. For uncountable graphs, we need cardinal-valued versions. Since Mathlib doesn't directly provide this, we axiomatize the relevant properties.

title: Question 1 (OPEN)
content: **Question1**: Is there a graph with ℵ₂ vertices and chromatic number ℵ₂ where every ℵ₁-sized induced subgraph has chromatic number at most ℵ₀?
mathContext: This asks if 'global' chromatic number ℵ₂ can coexist with 'local' countable chromaticity. The graph would need uncountably many colors globally, but any subgraph of size ℵ₁ could be colored with countably many colors.

title: Question 2 (OPEN)
content: **Question2**: Is there a graph with ℵ_{ω+1} vertices and chromatic number ℵ₁ where every ℵ_ω-sized induced subgraph has chromatic number at most ℵ₀?
mathContext: Here ω is the first infinite ordinal (Ordinal.omega0). ℵ_ω = sup{ℵ_n : n < ω} is a limit cardinal, and ℵ_{ω+1} is its successor. This question involves larger cardinals than Question 1.

title: Erdős-Hajnal Finite Case (SOLVED)
content: **erdos_hajnal_finite**: For every finite k, there exists a graph with ℵ_k vertices and chromatic number ℵ₁ where all subgraphs on fewer than ℵ_k vertices have chromatic number ≤ ℵ₀.
mathContext: This is the SOLVED part of Problem #918. The construction uses transfinite induction on k. For k=1, we need an ℵ₁-vertex graph that is ℵ₁-chromatic but where all countable subgraphs are countably chromatic.

title: Impossibility of Exact ℵ₀
content: **eq_aleph0_impossible_statement**: The original problem in [Er69b] asked for chromatic number *exactly* ℵ₀, not *at most* ℵ₀. But this is trivially impossible!
mathContext: Any graph contains finite subgraphs (like single edges or triangles) with finite chromatic number. So we cannot require ALL subgraphs to have chromatic number exactly ℵ₀. The corrected version uses ≤ ℵ₀.

title: Aleph Cardinal Hierarchy
content: We establish basic facts about aleph cardinals: ℵ₀ = |ℕ|, ℵ₀ < ℵ₁ < ℵ₂, and ℵ_ω is the supremum of all finite alephs.
mathContext: The aleph hierarchy: ℵ₀ (countable), ℵ₁ (first uncountable), ℵ₂ (next uncountable), etc. ℵ_ω is a limit cardinal - it's the supremum but has no immediate predecessor. ℵ_{ω+1} is the successor of ℵ_ω.

title: Why This Problem is Hard
content: The jump from finite k to ℵ₂ (or ℵ_{ω+1}) is fundamentally different. The combinatorial methods for finite k don't generalize, and the answer may depend on set-theoretic axioms beyond ZFC.
mathContext: This connects to **compactness** in graph theory: can large chromatic number always be witnessed by a smaller subgraph? Erdős-Hajnal shows this fails at finite thresholds, but the infinite case is open.

title: Summary Theorem
content: **erdos_918_summary** packages the proved facts: ℵ₀ < ℵ₁ and ℵ₁ < ℵ₂. This demonstrates the strict ordering of the aleph cardinals relevant to the problem.
mathContext: This is a genuine proved theorem (not axiom) that follows from our axioms about aleph ordering. It confirms the cardinal hierarchy needed to understand the problem statements.
